001package org.krmdemo.techlabs.core.utils;
002
003import java.util.Arrays;
004import java.util.List;
005import java.util.Map;
006import java.util.stream.Collector;
007import java.util.stream.Collectors;
008import java.util.stream.Stream;
009
010import static org.krmdemo.techlabs.core.utils.CountingUtils.countingMap;
011
012/**
013 * Utility-class to work with strings, words and characters
014 * (some extension to JDK and {@link org.apache.commons.lang3.StringUtils})
015 */
016public class CoreStringUtils {
017
018    /**
019     * Just a short-cut of JDK-invocation: <pre>{@code
020     *     Collectors.joining(System.lineSeparator())
021     * }</pre>
022     * @return the {@link Collector} that join the stream of strings with {@link System#lineSeparator()}
023     */
024    public static Collector<CharSequence, ?, String> multiLine() {
025        return Collectors.joining(System.lineSeparator());
026    }
027
028    /**
029     * @param str a string (eventually {@link CharSequence} to get the stream of chars
030     * @return the stream of chars as {@link Stream Stream&lt;Character&gt;}
031     */
032    public static Stream<Character> streamChars(CharSequence str) {
033        return str.chars().mapToObj(ch -> (char)ch);
034    }
035
036    public static Map<Character, Integer> countingCharsMap(CharSequence str) {
037        return countingMap(streamChars(str));
038    }
039
040    public static Stream<String> splitWords(String sentence) {
041        return Arrays.stream(sentence.split("\\W"))
042            .map(String::trim)
043            .filter(word -> !word.isEmpty());
044    }
045
046    public static List<String> splitWordsList(String sentence) {
047        return splitWords(sentence).collect(Collectors.toList());
048    }
049
050    /**
051     * The same as {@link Collectors#joining(CharSequence)} with empty delimiter,
052     * but the elements of string are concatenated in <b>reversed order</b>.
053     * <hr/>
054     * <u><i>Note:</i></u> Not use for large streams, because  {@link StringBuilder#insert(int, Object)}
055     * is much slower than {@link StringBuilder#append(Object)} when the length of buffer is very big.
056     *
057     * @return the result as {@link CharSequence} (no extra copy of the result!)
058     * @param <T> the type of input elements to the reduction operation
059     */
060    public static <T> Collector<T, ?, CharSequence> joiningReversed() {
061        return joiningReversed("");
062    }
063
064    /**
065     * The same as {@link Collectors#joining(CharSequence)},
066     * but the elements of string are concatenated in <b>reversed order</b>.
067     * <hr/>
068     * <u><i>Note:</i></u> Not use for large streams, because  {@link StringBuilder#insert(int, Object)}
069     * is much slower than {@link StringBuilder#append(Object)} when the length of buffer is very big.
070     *
071     * @return the result as {@link CharSequence} (no extra copy of the result!)
072     * @param <T> the type of input elements to the reduction operation
073     */
074    public static <T> Collector<T, ?, CharSequence> joiningReversed(String delimiter) {
075        return joiningReversed(delimiter, "", "");
076    }
077
078    /**
079     * The same as {@link Collectors#joining(CharSequence, CharSequence, CharSequence)},
080     * but the elements of string are concatenated in <b>reversed order</b>.
081     * <hr/>
082     * <u><i>Note:</i></u> Not use for large streams, because  {@link StringBuilder#insert(int, Object)}
083     * is much slower than {@link StringBuilder#append(Object)} when the length of buffer is very big.
084     *
085     * @return the result as {@link CharSequence} (no extra copy of the result!)
086     * @param <T> the type of input elements to the reduction operation
087     */
088    public static <T> Collector<T, ?, CharSequence> joiningReversed(String delimiter, String prefix, String suffix) {
089        return Collector.of(
090            StringBuilder::new,
091            (sb, value) -> {
092                if (!sb.isEmpty() && !delimiter.isEmpty()) {
093                    sb.insert(0, delimiter);
094                }
095                sb.insert(0, value);
096            },
097            (left, right) -> { // the combiner is required for parallel streams
098                right.append(delimiter).append(left); return right;
099            },
100            sb -> sb.insert(0, prefix).append(suffix)
101        );
102    }
103}
